REACHING AN AGREEMENT
With the appointment of a committee by the President of the
Interfraternity Board to draw up a rushing agreement for next year

begins the annual fraternity war. Only the completion of examinations was necessary before the body of embryo diplomats 'started to
formulate tentative agreements. Needless to say, each fraternity
has its own special idea and suggestions regarding an ideal rushing
season which will be most favorable for its chapter. As a result at
least ten different plans are presented to the committee for consideration. Long, tedious, and to a great extent, unnecessary discussions
and disagreements follow throughout the spring months. A fraternity is always reluctant in wavering its idea of an ideal system, and,
in some cases, unwilling even to listen to the proposals of other fraternities. Wrong impressions, individual and fraternal malice are

Tickets $2.20

The whole undergraduate department must get the spirit of the
players and permeate this spirit far
and wide. Certainly, if your father
isn't grouchy at breakfast you can
talk it over with him then. Perhaps
a pretty freshman can offer to take
his girl and then (if he wants to
be generous) offer his parents three
or four tickets at $2.20 per. It's
not hard—people clamor for the
best seats and children cry for more.
It's all a matter of talking the thing
over. The Freshmen, right out of
a nightmare called high school,
ought to do wonders.
HERR KRACIIZEN.

bound to be a consequence, if this year is to be no exception. This
discussion continues, old minutes of the Interfraternity Board will
show, far into the spring. Compromises are made later in order to
not so much for the sake of reaching an agreement as to smooth over
hard feeling or to cover up initial stubbornness. Then, usually about
a week before the cessation of classes, all the fraternities sign an
agreement.
This rather unfortunate circumstance of long discussion and
the resulting interfraternity ill-feeling is due to a general lack of coordination among the members of the Interfraternity Board. The
cause for this appears to be a result of the individual chapters restricting the power of their delegates 'so that the delegate cannot act
finally. With the majority of fraternities, the representatives are required to report buck to their chapters every detail before entering
a compromise or taking definite action. Appointment by each fraternity of delegates to the Interfraternity Board capable of drawing up
a rushing agreement and empowered by their respective chapters to
act on their own initiative, to accept or reject plans at the Board
meeting without acting as messenger boys carrying the news from
the Board to their chapters, would obviate the long discussions which
hitherto have characterized the former spring sessions and undoubtedly caused much hard feeling among fraternities. An agreement
made in this way would hardly be inferior to the ones of previous
seasons.

ATHLETICALLY DEAD

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
Johns Hopkins' athletic reputation is being lowered by the 192425 season. Last year the honored
name of Johns Hopkins was spread
throughout the country. Our teams
won renown in each branch of
sport. The football team astonished
the critics by holding to a tie the
strong University of Maryland
team, which had outplayed and
nearly conquered Yale, and had defeated Pennsylvania. Last year's
cross country team, with Verne
Booth as its leader, won fame for
Hopkins when Booth won both the
National A. A. U. and the Intercollegiate cross country championships. This year we have no cross
country team. Why is this? Some
say lack of material, but surely
there are enough able men in this
university to form a representative
team.
Lacrosse, as usual, turned out to be
a triumph for Hopkins. The team
defeated the best in the country
and won the Southern Intercollegiate Championship. Hopkins was
also tied with Syracuse, the North-

FELIX, the well-known catawumpus of the screen, wrote
to us the other day and said he wanted to work his way to
Europe. The star catterback of the Catown eleven crashed
his "mid-terms" harder than he ever hit an opposing feline
line, and received a pink unconditional release, good until
September, 1925.
Felix explained in his letter that he was in the pink of
condition and was willing to stoke, peel potatoes, or catch
rats bare-handed. We wrote Felix that Cunard ships were
all oil-driven and needed no stokers, and as for rats on a
Cunard ship, why they just didn't exist. We also asked
Felix if he had heard of our new College Cabin service for
Congenial Cats—Clean and Comfy. Evidently he hadn't,
for he's just telegraphed us to "send him the dope." We
wired back—
FELIX, MU MU HOUSE

the French Club to present "The

first half year. Meetings during
their inaugural period have been
held once each week when speakers
addressed the members.

officers were held with the following
result: President, Shapiro; VicePresident, Hecht; Secretary, Wiesenfeld ; Treasurer, Hoffman.

REACHING AN AGREEMENT
With the appointment of a committee by the President of the
Interfraternity Board to draw up a rushing agreement for next year

begins the annual fraternity war. Only the completion of examinations was necessary before the body of embryo diplomats 'started to
formulate tentative agreements. Needless to say, each fraternity
has its own special idea and suggestions regarding an ideal rushing
season which will be most favorable for its chapter. As a result at
least ten different plans are presented to the committee for consideration. Long, tedious, and to a great extent, unnecessary discussions
and disagreements follow throughout the spring months. A fraternity is always reluctant in wavering its idea of an ideal system, and,
in some cases, unwilling even to listen to the proposals of other fraternities. Wrong impressions, individual and fraternal malice are

bound to be a consequence, if this year is to be no exception. This
discussion continues, old minutes of the Interfraternity Board will
show, far into the spring. Compromises are made later in order to
not so much for the sake of reaching an agreement as to smooth over
hard feeling or to cover up initial stubbornness. Then, usually about
a week before the cessation of classes, all the fraternities sign an
agreement.
This rather unfortunate circumstance of long discussion and
the resulting interfraternity ill-feeling is due to a general lack of coordination among the members of the Interfraternity Board. The
cause for this appears to be a result of the individual chapters restricting the power of their delegates 'so that the delegate cannot act
finally. With the majority of fraternities, the representatives are required to report buck to their chapters every detail before entering
a compromise or taking definite action. Appointment by each fraternity of delegates to the Interfraternity Board capable of drawing up
a rushing agreement and empowered by their respective chapters to
act on their own initiative, to accept or reject plans at the Board
meeting without acting as messenger boys carrying the news from
the Board to their chapters, would obviate the long discussions which
hitherto have characterized the former spring sessions and undoubtedly caused much hard feeling among fraternities. An agreement
made in this way would hardly be inferior to the ones of previous
seasons.

ATHLETICALLY DEAD

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
Johns Hopkins' athletic reputation is being lowered by the 192425 season. Last year the honored
name of Johns Hopkins was spread
throughout the country. Our teams
won renown in each branch of
sport. The football team astonished
the critics by holding to a tie the
strong University of Maryland
team, which had outplayed and
nearly conquered Yale, and had defeated Pennsylvania. Last year's
cross country team, with Verne
Booth as its leader, won fame for
Hopkins when Booth won both the
National A. A. U. and the Intercollegiate cross country championships. This year we have no cross
country team. Why is this? Some
say lack of material, but surely
there are enough able men in this
university to form a representative
team.
Lacrosse, as usual, turned out to be
a triumph for Hopkins. The team
defeated the best in the country
and won the Southern Intercollegiate Championship. Hopkins was
also tied with Syracuse, the North-

FELIX, the well-known catawumpus of the screen, wrote
to us the other day and said he wanted to work his way to
Europe. The star catterback of the Catown eleven crashed
his "mid-terms" harder than he ever hit an opposing feline
line, and received a pink unconditional release, good until
September, 1925.
Felix explained in his letter that he was in the pink of
condition and was willing to stoke, peel potatoes, or catch
rats bare-handed. We wrote Felix that Cunard ships were
all oil-driven and needed no stokers, and as for rats on a
Cunard ship, why they just didn't exist. We also asked
Felix if he had heard of our new College Cabin service for
Congenial Cats—Clean and Comfy. Evidently he hadn't,
for he's just telegraphed us to "send him the dope." We
wired back—
FELIX, MU MU HOUSE

Club Ends First Half Year; Election of

Preparations are being made by
the French Club to present "The
Man Who Married a Dumb Wife,"
by Anatole France, at the Homewood Playshop. If the plans under the direction of Mr. SilM culminate the production will be played
entirely in French.
The club has just completed its
first half year. Meetings during
their inaugural period have been
held once each week when speakers
addressed the members.
At a recent meeting election of
officers were held with the following
result: President, Shapiro; VicePresident, Hecht; Secretary, Wiesenfeld ; Treasurer, Hoffman.
